articles.headline: Worries That the Good Times Were Mostly a Mirage
articles.snippet: These days, the great moderation isn’t looking so great — or so moderate.
articles.abstract: These days, the great moderation isn’t looking so great — or so moderate.
articles.lead_paragraph: So, how bad could this get?

articles.headline: Bank of America Joins Parade of Mortgage-Related Losses
articles.snippet: The bank cited huge write-downs of mortgage-related securities and higher provisions for future losses in credit card and home equity loans.
articles.abstract: The bank cited huge write-downs of mortgage-related securities and higher provisions for future losses in credit card and home equity loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The upheaval in the mortgage market, a slowing economy and an increasingly stretched consumer have made the last few quarters among the toughest since Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, took over in 2001.

articles.headline: Rise of Chávez Sends Venezuelans to Florida
articles.snippet: The influx is reminiscent of the Cuban migration spurred by Fidel Castro’s overthrow of Fulgencio Batista in 1959.
articles.abstract: The influx is reminiscent of the Cuban migration spurred by Fidel Castro’s overthrow of Fulgencio Batista in 1959.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTON, Fla.  In December 2002, Ariel Dunaevschi, then the owner of a furniture business in Caracas, Venezuela, was on vacation in New York with his family when opponents of President Hugo Chávez called a crippling labor strike hoping to bring the government to its knees.

articles.headline: Borrowers With Good Credit May Benefit
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s decision to cut interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point should offer some comfort to consumers, with limits.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s decision to cut interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point should offer some comfort to consumers, with limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s decision on Tuesday to cut interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point should offer some comfort to consumers, with limits.

articles.headline: Urgently, Washington Responds to Fast-Spreading Market Turbulence
articles.snippet: As global markets swooned, Washington’s goal of projecting calm to the public crosses party lines.
articles.abstract: As global markets swooned, Washington’s goal of projecting calm to the public crosses party lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even though Monday was a holiday, Ben S. Bernanke showed up early at his office at the Federal Reserve. The next day, he was planning a trip to New York.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: On Wall Street, a Day of Frayed Nerves
articles.snippet: A dizzying somersault on the markets on Tuesday left traders and investors biting their nails and wondering  what lay ahead.
articles.abstract: A dizzying somersault on the markets on Tuesday left traders and investors biting their nails and wondering  what lay ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dan MacMillan was fearing the worst on Tuesday morning. Like many Wall Street traders he expected share prices to plummet after two days of severe declines in overseas markets.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Anxiety Crashes the Party at Davos
articles.snippet: This year, the World Economic Forum is actually going to be about the world economy. Which is not to say that there won’t be fun.
articles.abstract: This year, the World Economic Forum is actually going to be about the world economy. Which is not to say that there won’t be fun.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland  There was George Soros hunched over a dinner table, deep in conversation with a nodding companion. Howard Stringer of Sony ran into Mickey Schulhof, who once ran Sony’s American arm. And Klaus Schwab, the impresario of the World Economic Forum, welcomed an A-list crowd to a twinkling ballroom at the Hotel Belvedere.

articles.headline: Fed’s Action Stems Sell-Off in World Markets
articles.snippet: Confronting panic about a possible recession, the Federal Reserve announced the biggest one-day reduction of interest rates on record.
articles.abstract: Confronting panic about a possible recession, the Federal Reserve announced the biggest one-day reduction of interest rates on record.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, confronted by deepening panic in global financial markets about a possible recession in the United States, struck back on Tuesday morning with the biggest one-day reduction of interest rates on record and at least temporarily stopped a vertigo-inducing plunge in stock prices.
